moon_phases.fact: During a new moon, the moon is positioned between the Earth and the Sun, with its dark side facing Earth.
During a waxing crescent phase, the moon appears as a crescent shape and is visible in the western sky after sunset.
The first quarter moon is often called a half-moon, as half of its surface is illuminated and visible from Earth.
In a waxing gibbous phase, the moon is more than half illuminated but less than full, appearing as a bulging disc.
During a full moon, the entire face of the moon that is visible from Earth is illuminated by sunlight.
In a waning gibbous phase, the moon is still more than half illuminated, but the illuminated portion is decreasing.
The last quarter moon appears as a half-moon shape, with the left half illuminated. It rises around midnight and sets around noon.
During a waning crescent phase, only a small crescent of the moon is visible, and it is seen in the eastern sky before sunrise.
